billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO HOUSING, CONSTRUCTION AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT

title: Increases the ability to remove persons from premises used for illegal purposes
summary: Increases the ability to remove persons from premises used for illegal purposes; enables tenants, block associations and community organizations within 1,000 feet of a property being used for an illegal activity to serve owners with a written notice requiring the owner to make application for the removal of the person using the premises for illegal activities and allows such organizations to bring a proceeding when the owner fails to act.
lawSection: Real Property Actions and Proceedings Law

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2221

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the real property actions and proceedings law, in relation
to grounds and procedures to recover premises where use or
occupancy is illegal

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill amends the Real
Property Actions and
Proceedings Law (RPAPL) by amending Section 715 to remove archaic
terms and enhance its use to remove occupants conducting illegal
activities in the building. This bill would make the following
changes to the statute:

1. Provide for a more reasonable time period in which an owner is
required to initiate a proceeding under Article 7 from the current
five days to 20 days after a notice to initiate an eviction is served;

2. Provides an owner the right to have the legal basis of the notice
served upon him requiring removal of a tenant clarified;

3. Adds tenant and community organizations to the current parties that
have standing to initiate notice requiring an owner to initiate the
removal of a person using a premises for an illegal activity and adds
these groups to the current parties that can bring a proceeding under
Article 7 to remove an occupant conducting an illegal activity where
an owner fails to act;

4. A presumptive value for criminal convictions involving controlled
substance and marijuana are added as equivalents to those that exist
for gambling and prostitution;

5. The burden of proof is set expressly as preponderance of the
evidence;

6. A blanket requirement for criminal convictions is expressly rejected;

7. The need for a notice to cure is expressly rejected.

REASONS FOR SUPPORT:
This long standing law has
recently been utilized
as a mechanism to evict drug dealers from properties. The Bawdy House
Law is a statutory conferral of standing to parties whose lives and
property are affected by the presence of an illegal activity in their
neighborhoods. The grounds for initiating an action is similar to the
basis for initiating an action in the public nuisance law, where a
person affected by a nuisance may bring an action for abatement and
damages against the person causing the nuisance. The statutory

conferral of standing is not unique and parallels provisions in the
Multiple Dwelling Law, the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law and the
State Finance Law.

This bill updates and clarifies the Bawdy House Law to make it a more
effective tool to rid buildings of drug dealers and drug dens. This
legislation would delete archaic and outdated terms and provide more
reasonable notice and proceeding timetables. The bill would also
expand the grounds to evict and recover a premises to include the
possession of controlled substances. Community and tenant
organizations can provide effective assistance in the fight to rid
building of drug dealers and drug dens. The Bawdy House Law gives
special standing to persons located within 200 feet of an illegal
business. The bill adds to the current list of those with standing,
tenant and community organizations and enables all persons with
standing that are within 1,000 feet of a premises where illegal
activity is taking place to serve owners with a written notice of
illegal activity and requiring them to initiate a proceeding to
evict. Where owners fail to act, the bill will add these
organizations to those that already have standing to bring a
proceeding to remove the occupant conducting an illegal activity. In
addition, the bill expands the unrealistic time frame established in
the Bawdy House Law to initiate a proceeding from five to 20 days and
provides
owners with the right to have the legal basis of the notice that
is served upon them by tenants or qualified organizations clarified.

The bill also codifies several important points which have been
seriously contested in recent cases commenced pursuant to the Bawdy
House Law. First, the bill provides that notices to cure and notice
of termination are not required in this type of case. Authorities
have held that these notices are reasonable only when a tenant's or
subtenant's conduct is in violation of a provision of the lease but
never when it is in violation of the law. Second, the bill expressly
identifies selling narcotics as one of the illegal businesses which
provide the grounds for an eviction. The retail and wholesale selling
of narcotics from inside a multiple dwelling is a modern phenomenon
and should be clearly identified as an illegal business. Third, this
bill sets the preponderance of evidence as the standard of proof that
the petitioner must carry. Fourth, it expressly rejects the notion
that criminal convictions are a prerequisite to the commencement of
actions of this type. Finally, the bill increases the potential
amount of the civil fine for non-compliance which is paid to a
municipality from $5,000 to $10,000.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately.
